facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 196 of 1958 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 196 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 27, 1953, of the Assam High Court in Civil Rule No. 66 of 1953.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 27, 1953 of Assam High Court in Civil Rule No. 66 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 27, 1953, of the Assam High Court in Civil Rule No. 66 of 1953. Sukumar Mitter and Sukumar Ghose, for the appel. lant. Veda Vyasa and Naunit Lal, for the respondents.

facts.text: Appellants are dealers registered under the Assam Sales Tax Act XVII of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are dealers registered under the Assam Sales Tax Act XVII of 1947-hereinafter referred to as the Act. For the account period April 1, 1948 to September 30, 1948, the appellants submitted a return of their turnover which included sales in Assam of all goods other than jute.

facts.text: For account period April 1, 1948 to September 30, 1948, appellants submitted return of turnover including sales in Assam of all goods other than jute.

anchor.surface_text: For the account period April 1, 1948 to September 30, 1948, the appellants submitted a return of their turnover which included sales in Assam of all goods other than jute. The Superintendent of Taxes, Dhubri, summarily assessed the appellants under sub-s. 4 of s. 17 of the Act to pay tax on sales of jute despatched by them to Calcutta during the account period.

facts.text: Superintendent of Taxes, Dhubri, summarily assessed appellants under sub-s. 4 of s. 17 of the Act to pay tax on sales of jute despatched by them to Calcutta during the account period April 1, 1948 to September 30, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The Superintendent of Taxes, Dhubri, summarily assessed the appellants under sub-s. 4 of s. 17 of the Act to pay tax on sales of jute despatched by them to Calcutta during the account period. Appeals against the order of assessment to the Assistant Commissioner of Taxes and to the Commissioner of Taxes, Assam, proved unsuccessful.

facts.text: Appeals against the order of assessment to Assistant Commissioner of Taxes and Commissioner of Taxes, Assam, proved unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals against the order of assessment to the Assistant Commissioner of Taxes and to the Commissioner of Taxes, Assam, proved unsuccessful. The appellants then applied to the Commissioner of Taxes to refer certain questions arising out of the assessment to the High Court in Assam under S. 34 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellants applied to Commissioner of Taxes to refer questions to High Court under s.34 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then applied to the Commissioner of Taxes to refer certain questions arising out of the assessment to the High Court in Assam under S. 34 of the Act. The Commissioner referred the following questions and another to the High Court of Judicature in Assam

facts.text: Commissioner referred questions to High Court: Whether turnover from 20,515 maunds of jute under item i is taxable under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether, in view of the aforesaid facts and circumstances the turnover from 20,515 maunds of 6 jute mentioned under item  i  is taxable under the Act ? Whether, in view of the aforesaid facts and circumstances the turnover from 5,500 maunds of jute mentioned under item  ii  is taxable under the Act ?

facts.text: High Court answered for each question: Not being a sale within the meaning of sub-s.12 of s.2 of the Act, the consignments are not taxable.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of each of the three questions 1 to 3, the High Court recorded the following answer Not being a sale within the meaning of sub12 of s. 2 of the Act, the companysignments are riot taxable . The High Court, however observed

facts.text: High Court observed: As to whether these consignments can hereafter be assessed if they fall within the purview of the Explanation to sub-s.12 of s.2, we express no opinion.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however observed As to whether these companysignments can hereafter be assessed if they fall within the purview of the Explanation to sub-s. 12 of s. 2, we express numberopinion . As required by s. 32 8  of the Act, the Commissioner of Taxes by his order dated August 1, 1952,

facts.text: Commissioner of Taxes by order dated August 1, 1952 directed Superintendent of Taxes to dispose of the case in accordance with High Court judgment under s.32(8).

anchor.surface_text: As required by s. 32 8  of the Act, the Commissioner of Taxes by his order dated August 1, 1952, directed the Superintendent of Taxes to dispose of the case in accordance with the judgment of the High Court.

facts.text: Superintendent of Taxes issued notice on January 30, 1953 to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The Superintendent of Taxes thereafter issued on January 30, 1953, the following numberice to the appellants In view of the Honble High Courts order in Sales-tax Reference No. 3 of 1951, the assessment order dated 30th September, 1950,

facts.text: Notice stated assessment order dated 30th September, 1950 for return period 30th September, 1948 set aside, produce evidence to see if within Explanation to s.2(12).

anchor.surface_text: In view of the Honble High Courts order in Sales-tax Reference No. 3 of 1951, the assessment order dated 30th September, 1950, for the return period 30th September, 1948, has been set aside and you are directed to produce necessary evidence, company. tract papers, account books, etc

facts.text: Appellants by letter dated March 23, 1953 called upon Commissioner to direct Superintendent not to proceed with notice.

anchor.surface_text: By their letter dated March 23, 1953, the appellants called upon the Commissioner of Taxes to direct the Superintendent of Taxes number to proceed with the numberice. The Commissioner having failed to direct as requested,

facts.text: Commissioner failed to direct Superintendent as requested by appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner having failed to direct as requested, the appellant petitioned the High Court in Assam under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a writ prohibiting the Superintendent of Taxes from re-opening and proceeding with the assessment

facts.text: Appellants petitioned Assam High Court under Art. 226 for writ prohibiting Superintendent from re-opening assessment and quashing Commissioner order dated August 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant petitioned the High Court in Assam under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a writ prohibiting the Superintendent of Taxes from re-opening and proceeding with the assessment of the appellants under the Assam Sales Tax Act and for a writ quashing the order dated August 1, 1952, passed by the Commissioner.

facts.text: High Court summarily dismissed the petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court summarily dismissed the petition. Against the order passed by the High Court, this appeal is filed with special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appeal filed in Supreme Court with special leave under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the High Court, this appeal is filed with special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution. The High Court, in answering the questions submitted to it, was exercising an advisory jurisdiction

facts.text: Supreme Court held Superintendent of Taxes acted without authority in issuing notice to re-open assessment.

anchor.surface_text: In so doing, the Superintendent of Taxes, in our judgment, acted without authority. The Superintendent had made the assessment, and that assessment was companyfirmed in appeal by the Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: No notice issued under s.19 or s.19A by Commissioner, no revisional order under s.31.

anchor.surface_text: But the Commissioner bad number issued any such numberice under s. 19A. Nor had the Commissioner in exercise of his revisional authority under s. 31 of the Act set aside the original order of assessment.

facts.text: Proceedings for reassessment barred as three years from end of account period expired before notice dated January 30, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: In any event, the account period as has already been observed was April 1, 1948 to September 30, 1948, and three years from the end of that period, expired before the date on which the numberice was issued.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court order, directed writ quashing notice dated January 30, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must therefore be allowed and the order passed by the High Court set aside. In the circumstances of the case, numberuseful purpose will be served by remanding the case to the High Court. We accordingly direct that a writ quashing the proceedings companymenced by the Superintendent of Taxes, Dhubri, by his numberice dated January 30, 1953, be issued.

issues.text: Whether the High Court in answering the questions submitted to it under s.34 was exercising an advisory jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, in answering the questions submitted to it, was exercising an advisory jurisdiction and could neither and did neither give any direction to the sales tax authorities to proceed to assess or not to assess the appellants to sales tax it merely recorded its opinion that the transactions referred to in the questions were not sales within the meaning of s. 2, sub-s. 12, of the Act and were accordingly not taxable.

issues.text: Whether the Superintendent of Taxes had authority under the Act to re-open the assessment proceedings and issue notice dated January 30, 1953 requiring production of evidence, contract papers etc. to determine whether transactions fell within the Explanation to s.2(12)

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the opinion of the High Court, the Commissioner directed the Superintendent of Taxes to dispose of the case in accordance with the judgment of the High Court but the Superintendent of Taxes thought that he was entitled to re-open the assessment proceedings and to assess the appellants in the light of the Explanation to s. 2, sub- s. 12. In so doing, the Superintendent of Taxes, in our judgment, acted without authority.

Bombay Trust Corporation Ltd.

arguments.claim: Bombay Trust principle does not apply as no revisional authority exercised by Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: The principle of this case has in our judgment numberapplication to the present case. The High Court at Bombay in its advisory jurisdiction had declared the assessment already made to be illegal. But the Commissioner was under s. 33 of the Indian Income-tax Act invested with jurisdiction to direct further enquiry, and he purported to exercise that jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The High Court, in answering the questions submitted to it, was exercising an advisory jurisdiction and could neither and did neither give any direction to the sales tax authorities to proceed to assess or not to assess the appellants to sales tax it merely recorded its opinion that the transactions referred to in the questions were not sales within the meaning of s. 2, sub-s. 12, of the Act and were accordingly not taxable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court under s.34 provides opinion only, without binding directions to tax authorities.

holdings.text: In so doing, the Superintendent of Taxes, in our judgment, acted without authority.

anchor.surface_text: In so doing, the Superintendent of Taxes, in our judgment, acted without authority. The Superintendent had made the assessment, and that assessment was confirmed in appeal by the Assistant Commissioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Original assessment confirmed; High Court opinion vacated it but no statutory power invoked for further inquiry; s.32(8) direction limited to compliance with judgment.

holdings.text: But admittedly, the appellants were registered as dealers and had submitted their returns the power to reassess could not therefore be exercised by virtue of s. 19 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that under s. 19 of the Act, the taxation Officer if satisfied upon information coming into his possession that any dealer has been liable to pay tax under the Act in respect of any period and has failed to apply for registration and to make the

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.19 applies only to failure to register or file returns; appellants complied.

holdings.text: But the Commissioner had not issued any such notice under s. 19A. Nor had the Commissioner in exercise of his revisional authority under s. 31 of the Act set aside the original order of assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No notice under s.19A; no revisional order under s.31 to set aside assessment.

holdings.text: The Commissioner merely directed under s. 32, sub-s. 8, that the case be disposed of in accordance with the judgment of the High Court, and acting under that direction, the Superintendent of Taxes had no power to reopen the assessment and to call upon the appellants to produce documentary evidence with a view to commence an enquiry whether the sales involved in the case fell within the purview of the Explanation to s. 2 sub-s. 12.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner merely directed under s. 32, sub-s. 8, that the case be disposed of in accordance with the judgment of the High Court, and acting under that direction, the Superintendent of Taxes had no power to reopen the assessment and to call upon

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.32(8) requires disposal per High Court judgment; does not authorize new inquiry or evidence production.

holdings.text: In any event, the account period as has already been observed was April 1, 1948 to September 30, 1948, and three years from the end of that period, expired before the date on which the notice was issued.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notice issued after 3-year limitation under ss.19/19A from end of account period.

holdings.text: The principle of this case has in our judgment no application to the present case.

anchor.surface_text: The principle of this case has in our judgment no application to the present case. The High Court at Bombay in its advisory jurisdiction had declared the assessment already made to be illegal. But the Commissioner was under s. 33 of the Indian Income-tax

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished Bombay Trust: there, Commissioner exercised revisional power under IT Act s.33 to direct inquiry; here, no such revisional direction by Commissioner.

holdings.text: The appeal must therefore be allowed and the order passed by the High Court set aside... We accordingly direct that a writ quashing the proceedings commenced by the Superintendent of Taxes, Dhubri, by his notice dated January 30, 1953, be issued.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must therefore be allowed and the order passed by the High Court set aside. In the circumstances of the case, no useful purpose will be served by remanding the case to the High Court. We accordingly direct that a writ quashing the proceedings

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on lack of authority and limitation, appeal succeeds; writ under Art.226/136 to quash invalid notice.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay Presidency and Aden and others v. Bombay Trust Corporation Ltd.  1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay Presidency and Aden and others v. Bombay Trust Corporation Ltd.  1

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay Presidency and Aden and others v Bombay Trust Corporation Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Superintendent of Taxes had authority to proceed to reassess the appellants in the light of the observations made in the judgment of the High Court
precedents.cited_holding: the Commissioner was not obliged to discontinue proceedings against the resident company as agent of the foreign company in respect of the year of assessment, and it was within the jurisdiction of the Commissioner under s. 33 2  of the Income-tax Act to direct further enquiry if he thought such an enquiry to be reasonable and to be profitable in the public interest
